column3: Quality Assurance (QA) is the process of ensuring that a product or service meets specified requirements and standards before being released

column14: Quality Assurance (QA) is the process of ensuring that a product or service meets specified requirements and standards before being released  through testing  verification  and validation.

column2: What is the difference between Quality Assurance (QA) and Quality Control (QC)?
column3: Quality Assurance focuses on preventing defects by improving processes
column4: while Quality Control focuses on identifying defects in the final product.
column14: Quality Assurance focuses on preventing defects by improving processes  while Quality Control focuses on identifying defects in the final product.

column2: What are the different types of testing?
column3: The different types of testing include unit testing
column4: integration testing
column14: The different types of testing include unit testing  integration testing  system testing  acceptance testing  regression testing  and performance testing.

column3: Unit testing involves testing individual components or functions of a system to ensure they work as expected in isolation.
column14: Unit testing involves testing individual components or functions of a system to ensure they work as expected in isolation.

column3: Integration testing involves testing the interaction between different modules or components of a system to ensure they work together correctly.
column14: Integration testing involves testing the interaction between different modules or components of a system to ensure they work together correctly.

column3: System testing is a type of testing that evaluates the entire system's functionality to ensure that all components work as intended and meet the requirements.
column14: System testing is a type of testing that evaluates the entire system's functionality to ensure that all components work as intended and meet the requirements.

column3: Acceptance testing involves verifying that the product meets the business requirements and is ready for delivery to the client or end user.
column14: Acceptance testing involves verifying that the product meets the business requirements and is ready for delivery to the client or end user.

column3: Regression testing is the process of testing previously tested software to ensure that new changes or fixes have not introduced new defects.
column14: Regression testing is the process of testing previously tested software to ensure that new changes or fixes have not introduced new defects.

column3: Performance testing evaluates the speed
column4: scalability
column5: and reliability of a system under various conditions.
column14: Performance testing evaluates the speed  scalability  and reliability of a system under various conditions.

column3: Load testing is a type of performance testing that evaluates the system's ability to handle a specific load or number of users without degrading performance.
column14: Load testing is a type of performance testing that evaluates the system's ability to handle a specific load or number of users without degrading performance.

column3: Stress testing involves testing a system's behavior under extreme conditions or loads to determine its breaking point.
column14: Stress testing involves testing a system's behavior under extreme conditions or loads to determine its breaking point.

column3: Usability testing involves evaluating the user experience to ensure that the system is user-friendly
column4: efficient
column14: Usability testing involves evaluating the user experience to ensure that the system is user-friendly  efficient  and easy to use.

column3: Smoke testing is a preliminary test to check whether the basic functionality of the software works after a new build or update.
column14: Smoke testing is a preliminary test to check whether the basic functionality of the software works after a new build or update.

column3: Sanity testing involves checking specific functionalities of the system to ensure they work as expected
column4: often after bug fixes or minor changes.

column3: Black-box testing focuses on testing the system based on its functionality without knowledge of its internal workings or code.

column3: Acceptance criteria are specific conditions that a product must meet to be considered complete and acceptable by the stakeholders or client.
column14: Acceptance criteria are specific conditions that a product must meet to be considered complete and acceptable by the stakeholders or client.

column2: What is the difference between a bug and a defect?
column3: A bug is a fault or flaw in the software
column4: while a defect refers to any divergence from the expected behavior or requirements.

column3: A test case is a set of conditions or variables used to determine if a system or software behaves as expected under specific scenarios.

column4: approach
column7: as well as the objectives and deliverables.

column2: What is the purpose of a bug tracking tool?

column2: What is the purpose of regression testing?
